content: The Act titled "International Extradition Enforcement Act of 2001" requires an annual report on extradition efforts between the United States and foreign governments. The International Extradition Enforcement Act of 2001 mandates an annual report on extradition efforts between the United States and foreign governments. The report, prepared by the Secretary of State and the Attorney General, details efforts to extradite individuals held in custody by foreign governments for major extraditable offenses. The International Extradition Enforcement Act of 2001 requires an annual report on extradition efforts involving individuals held in custody by foreign governments for major offenses like murder, kidnapping, drug trafficking, and terrorism. The report must also include the number of individuals being held in custody. The International Extradition Enforcement Act of 2001 mandates an annual report on extradition efforts for individuals held in custody by foreign governments for serious offenses. The report must detail reasons for non-extradition to the US and actions taken to secure extradition. The International Extradition Enforcement Act of 2001 requires an annual report on extradition efforts for individuals held in custody by foreign governments for serious offenses. Section 3 of the Act imposes sanctions on foreign governments that are uncooperative in extradition efforts with the United States. The International Extradition Enforcement Act of 2001 imposes sanctions on foreign governments that are uncooperative in extradition efforts with the United States, prohibiting development and security assistance to identified governments. The International Extradition Enforcement Act of 2001 prohibits assistance to foreign governments uncooperative in extradition with the US. The President must oppose assistance proposals benefiting such governments and deny visas to high-ranking officials. The International Extradition Enforcement Act of 2001 prohibits assistance to foreign governments deemed uncooperative in extradition with the US. The President must identify annually uncooperative governments and consider their extradition policies towards the US. The International Extradition Enforcement Act of 2001 prohibits assistance to foreign governments deemed uncooperative in extradition with the US. The President must annually identify uncooperative governments based on their extradition policies towards the US, including failure to extradite US citizens or individuals involved in major offenses. The International Extradition Enforcement Act of 2001 prohibits assistance to foreign governments that hinder the extradition process with the US. The President must report uncooperative governments annually, and may waive assistance restrictions if it is in the vital national interests of the US. Congressional review allows for a joint resolution disapproving a certification by the President regarding a foreign government, leading to restrictions on funds for development and security assistance, opposition to multilateral assistance, and denial of visas for high-ranking officials. The Attorney General must establish formal complaint procedures related to the denial of extradition requests. The Attorney General will set up procedures for a State to submit a formal complaint if a foreign country fails to extradite individuals to the United States as requested. SEC. 4. CRIMINAL PENALTIES. The penalty for flight to avoid prosecution is increased to 15 years. A new law is added to penalize those who transfer anything of value to a person resisting extradition, with a maximum penalty of 10 years imprisonment. SEC. 5. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION: This Act and its amendments do not affect extradition treaties between the United States and foreign governments.
